Ingest_LDD.name: Imaging
Ingest_LDD.comment: This is a mission level dictionary containing high level classes and attributes used in Mars Pathfinder Mission products. It also contains classes with attributes used during active mission operations. The MPF LDD contains / uses references in the IMG LDD.

DD_Attribute.name: application_packet_name
DD_Attribute.definition: The application_packet_name attribute provides the name associated with the telemetry packet queue to which data were directed. Note: For Mars Pathfinder, the queues were distinguished on the basis of type and priority of data.

DD_Attribute.name: application_packet_id
DD_Attribute.definition: The application_packet_id attribute identifies the telemetry packet queue to which the data were directed.

DD_Attribute.name: command_name
DD_Attribute.definition: The command_name attribute provides the name of an uplinked command sent to a spacecraft or instrument.

DD_Attribute.name: command_description
DD_Attribute.definition: The command_description attribute provides a textual description associated with a command_name attribute.

DD_Attribute.name: tlm_cmd_discrepancy_flag
DD_Attribute.definition: The tlm_cmd_discrepancy_flag attribute indicates whether or not discrepancies were found between the uplinked commands and the downlinked telemetry.

DD_Attribute.name: download_type
DD_Attribute.definition: The download_type attribute specifies which data to download.

DD_Attribute.name: dark_current_download_flag
DD_Attribute.definition: The dark_current_download_flag attribute indicates whether or not an image of the dark strip area of the CCD was downlinked along with the image data.

DD_Attribute.name: sqrt_compression_flag
DD_Attribute.definition: The sqrt_compression_flag attribute indicates whether or not square root compression was applied to the image. Note: For MPF, this compression was performed onboard the lander, prior to transmission of the data to Earth. It involved the compression of the pixels from 12 bits down to 8 bits.

DD_Attribute.name: detector_pixel_height
DD_Attribute.definition: The detector_pixel_height attribute provides the height of a pixel in the Charge-Coupled Device (CCD) sensor measured in microns.

DD_Attribute.name: detector_pixel_width
DD_Attribute.definition: The detector_pixel_width attribute provides the width of a pixel in the Charge-Coupled Device (CCD) sensor measured in microns.

DD_Attribute.name: instrument_deployment_state
DD_Attribute.definition: The instrument_deployment_state attribute indicates the deployment state (i.e. physical configuration) of an instrument at the time of data acquisition. Note: For MPF, this referred to whether or not the IMP camera had been deployed to the end of its 62 cm mast at the time an image was acquired.

DD_Attribute.name: sol_number
DD_Attribute.definition:
The sol_number attribute indicates the number of sidereal days (rotation of 360 degrees) elapsed since a reference day (e.g., the day on which a landing vehicle set down). Days are measured in rotations of the planet in question from the reference day (which is day zero).
For MPF, the sol_number was measured from 1 rather than 0 as the first day of surface operations. Negative numbers referred to pre-surface (cruise) images.

DD_Attribute.name: spacecraft_clock_start_count
DD_Attribute.definition: The spacecraft_clock_start_count attribute provides the value of the spacecraft clock at the beginning of a time period of interest.

DD_Attribute.name: instrument_compression_synchronization_blocks
DD_Attribute.definition: The instrument_compression_synchronization_blocks attribute provides the number of blocks used to spatially segment a data product prior to compression.

DD_Attribute.name: rice_start_option
DD_Attribute.definition: The rice_start_option attribute is a RICE compressor specific variable that identifies the start option. Note: Information about RICE compression is available in JPL Document 91-D, November 15, 1991, 'Some Practical Universal Noiseless Coding Techniques, Part III.'

DD_Attribute.name: rice_option_value
DD_Attribute.definition: The rice_option_value attribute is a RICE compressor specific variable providing the number of options used by compression. Note: Information about RICE compression is available in JPL Document 91-D, November 15, 1991, 'Some Practical Universal Noiseless Coding Techniques, Part III.'

DD_Attribute.name: sqrt_minimum_pixel
DD_Attribute.definition: The sqrt_minimum_pixel attribute provides the minimum pixel value in an image prior to square root compression.

DD_Attribute.name: sqrt_maximum_pixel
DD_Attribute.definition: The sqrt_maximum_pixel attribute provides the maximum pixel value in an image prior to square root compression.

DD_Attribute.name: instrument_azimuth
DD_Attribute.definition: The instrument_azimuth attribute provides the value for an instrument's rotation in the horizontal direction. It is usually measured from some kind of low hard stop. Although it may be used for any instrument where it makes sense, it is primarily intended for use in surface-based instruments that measure pointing in terms of azimuth and elevation. When in a DERIVED_GEOMETRY group, defines the azimuth (horizontal rotation) at which the instrument is pointed. This value is expressed using the cooridinate system referred to by REFERENCE_COORD_SYSTEM_NAME and REFERENCE_COORD_SYSTEM_INDEX contained within the same group. The interpretation of exactly what part of the instrument is being pointed is missionspecific. It could be the boresight, the camera head direction, the CAHV camera model A vector direction, or any of a number of other things. As such, for multimission use this value should be used mostly as an approximation, e.g. identifying scenes which might contain a given object. The interpretation for MER is TBD.

DD_Attribute.name: azimuth_fov
DD_Attribute.definition: The azimuth_fov attribute provides the angular measure of the horizontal field of view of an imaged scene. Note: For MPF, 'horizontal' is measured in the x-y plane of the IMP coordinate system.

DD_Attribute.name: azimuth_motor_clicks
DD_Attribute.definition: The azimuth_motor_clicks attribute provides the number of motor step counts an instrument or other mechanism rotated in the horizontal direction from the low hard stop. Note: For MPF, each step count corresponded to 0.553 degrees. The valid range was 0 to 1023.

DD_Attribute.name: instrument_azimuth_method
DD_Attribute.definition: The instrument_azimuth_method identifies the method used to calculate the instrument azimuth from the azimuth motor clicks.

DD_Attribute.name: instrument_elevation
DD_Attribute.definition: The instrument_elevation attribute provides the value for the instrument's rotation in the vertical direction. It is usually measured from some kind of low hard stop. Although it may be used for any instrument where it makes sense, it is primarily intended for use in surface-based instruments that measure pointing in terms of azimuth and elevation. When specified as an attribute to the Derived_Geometry class, defines the elevation (vertical rotation) at which the instrument is pointed. This value is expressed using the coordinate system referred to by the Reference_Coordinate_Space class. The interpretation of exactly what part of the instrument is being pointed is mission-specific. It could be the boresight, the camera head direction, the CAHV camera model a vector direction, or any of a number of other things. As such, for multimission use this value should be used mostly as an approximation, (e.g., identifying scenes which might contain a given object).

DD_Attribute.name: elevation_fov
DD_Attribute.definition: The elevation_fov attribute provides the angular measure of the vertical field of view of an imaged scene. Note: For MPF, 'vertical' is measured along the ZIMP axis of the IMP coordinate system.

DD_Attribute.name: elevation_motor_clicks
DD_Attribute.definition: The elevation_motor_clicks attribute provides the number of motor step counts an instrument or other mechanism rotated in the vertical direction from the low hard stop. Note: For MPF, each step count corresponded to 0.553 degrees. The valid range was 0 to 1023.

DD_Attribute.name: instrument_elevation_method
DD_Attribute.definition: The instrument_elevation_method attribute identifies the method used to calculate the instrument elevation from the elevation motor clicks.

DD_Attribute.name: fixed_instrument_azimuth
DD_Attribute.definition: The fixed_instrument_azimuth attribute provides one of two angular measurements for the pointing direction of an instrument, measured with respect to a coordinate frame co-linear with the surface fixed coordinate frame. The azimuth is measured positively in the clockwise direction (as viewed from above) with the meridian passing through the positive spin axis ('north pole') defining the zero reference. The angle is measured in the local gravity horizontal plane, i.e., a plane perpendicular to the local gravity vector. The fixed_instrument_azimuth is derived from the instrument pointing and spacecraft orientation. It is co-linear with the surface fixed coordinate system, but the origin of the observation may not be coincident with the origin of the surface fixed frame. Note that the fixed_instrument_azimuth describes the pointing direction of the instrument rather than the angular coordinates of the target of the observation. If there has been any significant change over time in the position of the observing instrument (ie., the origin of the coordinate frame in which this value is measured), this attribute can not be used to uniquely describe the vector to a viewed object. See also fixed_instrument_elevation attribute.

DD_Attribute.name: fixed_instrument_elevation
DD_Attribute.definition: The fixed_instrument_elevation attribute provides one of two angular measurements of the pointing direction of an instrument, measured with respect to a coordinate frame co-linear with the surface fixed coordinate frame. The positive direction of the elevation is set by the positive_elevation_direction attribute. It is measured from the plane which is perpendicular to the local gravity vector and which intersects the elevation axis around which the instrument rotates. The fixed_instrument_elevation is derived from the instrument pointing and spacecraft orientation. It is co-linear with the surface fixed coordinate system, but the origin of the observation may not be co- incident with the origin of the surface fixed frame. Note that the fixed_instrument_elevation describes the pointing direction of the instrument rather than the angular coordinates of the target of the observation. If there has been any change over time in the position of the observing instrument (i.e., the origin of the coordinate frame in which this value is measured), this attribute can not be used to uniquely describe the vector to a viewed object. Assuming a flat surface, and combined with the instrument_altitude attribute, it can be used to determine the position of an object; however, given realistic non-flat surfaces, observations from another point of origin are required to determine an object's distance.

DD_Attribute.name: surface_based_inst_method
DD_Attribute.definition: The surface_based_inst_method attribute identifies the method used to calculate the surface based instrument pointing.

DD_Attribute.name: positive_elevation_direction
DD_Attribute.definition: The positive_elevation_direction attribute provides the direction in which elevation is measured in positive degrees for an observer on the surface of a body. The elevation is measured with respect to the azimuthal reference plane. A value of UP or ZENITH indicates that elevation is measured positively upwards, i.e., the zenith point would be at +90 degrees and the nadir point at -90 degrees. DOWN or NADIR indicates that the elevation is measured positively downwards; the zenith point would be at -90 degrees and the nadir point at +90 degrees.

DD_Attribute.name: solar_azimuth
DD_Attribute.definition: The solar_azimuth attribute provides one of two angular measurements indicating the direction to the sun as measured from a specific point on the surface of a planet (e.g., from a lander or rover). The azimuth is measured positively in the clockwise direction (as viewed from above) with the meridian passing through the positive spin axis of the planet (i.e., the north pole), defining the zero reference.

DD_Attribute.name: solar_elevation
DD_Attribute.definition: The solar_elevation attribute provides one of two angular measurements indicating the direction to the sun as measured from a specific point on the surface of a planet (e.g., from a lander or rover). The positive direction of the elevation, up or down, is set by the positive_elevation_direction attribute. It is measured from the plane which intersects the surface point and is normal to the line passing between the surface point and the planet's center of mass.

DD_Attribute.name: qcos
DD_Attribute.definition: One of the four components of a quaternion (Qcos, Qsin1, Qsin2, Qsin3). The order used in a quaternion depends on the 'style' of the quaternion.

DD_Attribute.name: qsin1
DD_Attribute.definition: One of the four components of a quaternion (Qcos, Qsin1, Qsin2, Qsin3). The order used in a quaternion depends on the 'style' of the quaternion.

DD_Attribute.name: qsin2
DD_Attribute.definition: One of the four components of a quaternion (Qcos, Qsin1, Qsin2, Qsin3). The order used in a quaternion depends on the 'style' of the quaternion.

DD_Attribute.name: qsin3
DD_Attribute.definition: One of the four components of a quaternion (Qcos, Qsin1, Qsin2, Qsin3). The order used in a quaternion depends on the 'style' of the quaternion.

DD_Class.name: Lander_Surface_Quaternion
DD_Class.definition: The Lander_Surface_Quaternion class provides an array of four values that define the relationship between the lander coordinate frame and the local level coordinate frame. These values are commonly listed in the order (cosine, x, y, z) or in the order (x, y, z, cosine).

DD_Class.name: MPF_Mission_Metadata
DD_Class.definition: The Mission_Metadata class contains attributes used to identify or describe the attributes specific to the MPF mission.

DD_Class.name: MPF_Discipline_Metadata
DD_Class.definition: The Discipline_Metadata class contains attributes used to identify or describe the attributes specific to the disciplines within the MPF mission.

DD_Class.name: MPF_Command_Parameters
DD_Class.definition: The MPF_Command_Parameters class contains attributes used to identify or describe the attributes specific to the command_parameters within the MPF mission.

DD_Class.name: MPF_Telemetry_Parameters
DD_Class.definition: The MPF_Telemetry_Parameters class contains attributes used to identify or describe the attributes specific to the telemetry_parameters within the MPF mission.

DD_Class.name: MPF_Compression_Parameters
DD_Class.definition: The MPF_Compression_Parameters class contains attributes used to identify or describe the attributes specific to the instrument_compression_parameters for the MPF mission.

DD_Class.name: MPF_Geometry_Parameters
DD_Class.definition: The MPF_Geometry_Parameters class contains attributes used to identify or describe the attributes specific to the geometry_parameters within the MPF mission.

Property_Map_Entry.property_value: For Mars Pathfinder, this specified any or all of: image data (IM), dark current strip (DS), and null pixel data (NS).
